abstract.text: Add a rule to find players in a range of skill levels to balance competitive gameplay.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Finding players with similar skill levels

inlineContent.text: When finding players using matchmaking rules, consider adding a rule that finds players in a range of skill levels to make gameplay more enjoyable and fair for all players. To reduce wait times for players, make the rule widen the skill range as the wait time, or age of the match request, increases.
This article shows one way to find players by skill level that you can combine with your other matchmaking rules. For other types of matchmaking rules, see
and

content.text: Create a skill-level rule set and queue

inlineContent.text: First create a rule set to contain the skill-level rule. Pass a reference name, the minimum players, and the maximum players properties that are game-specific to the

Retain the

Then create and add the rule set to a skill-level queue. Pass a reference name and the rule set that you create to the
endpoint. Pass the
for the rule set in the
object.

content.text: Choose parameters that work best for your game

inlineContent.text: You can create a matchmaking rule that initially attempts to match players with similar skill values, then after a few seconds, increases the skill range for another period of seconds. The rule repeats the increments at specified intervals until it reaches a maximum difference in skill levels.
For example, if the skill of players ranges from
to
in your game, create a rule that:
For the first
seconds, tries to find players with an ideal
points or less difference in skill level.
For the next
seconds, compromises to find players within
points or less difference in skill level.
After
seconds, finds players with no more than the maximum
points difference.
You choose the number of increments and the ranges of wait times and skill levels.

content.text: Write an expression that matches players by skill level

inlineContent.text: Write an expression for a match rule where the expression returns a Boolean value of
for an acceptable range of skill values that expands at specified time increments. An expression is a JMESPath formatted string with some Game Center matchmaking function additions.
First use the
function (see
) to compute the difference between the maximum and minimum skill values of players, where
is a game-specific property name that you set in your code when you submit a match request.
In a match rule, the requests array contains only compatible matches because Game Center applies compatible and distance rules before match rules.
Then use the
function to return a range of desired skill values depending on the average wait time or age of the requests. Compute the average age of the requests using the
function.
Pass the average age as the first parameter to the
function and other parameters depending on your game (see

Now compose a Boolean expression that compares the maximum difference in skill between compatible requests with the desired difference in skill as a function of wait time.
For more information on the Game Center functions you can use in expressions, see
in App Store Connect API.
If you have previous versions of your game that don’t provide player properties used in your rules, you can write expressions that provide default value for those properties. See

abstract.text: The data structure of the request body for the rule set.
The data structure that represents a rule set.
Create a queue and add it to a rule set.
Create a rule set to contain matchmaking rules and teams.
Add a matchmaking rule to a rule set.
Return the absolute difference between the maximum and minimum numerical values in an array.
Write expressions that query the match requests in a queue to find the best players for a match.
Return a value that changes according to an array of values as a function of the age of the requests.

abstract.text: A true value.
Enable players to interact with friends, compare leaderboard ranks, earn achievements, and participate in multiplayer games.
An object that encapsulates the parameters to create a real-time or turn-based match.
The criteria for the local player that Game Center uses to find other players when using matchmaking rules.
The name of the queue that Game Center places the match request in.
The criteria for recipients of the match request that Game Center uses to find other players when using matchmaking rules.
The players to invite to the match.
An object that creates matches with other players without presenting an interface to the players.
An interface that allows a player to invite other players to a real-time game and automatch to fill any empty slots.
Handles when the view controller finds players for a peer-to-peer match.
Set criteria for assigning players to teams in your game using matchmaking rules.

abstract.text: Game Center applies different type of rules you create in a particular order to find the best matches.
